topics.title: Why Clothes Became Fashion: From Function to Identity

hook.text: Animals grow fur. Humans chose what to wear â€” and that choice became culture, status, and self-expression.

buildup.text: Early clothing served survival: protection from cold, rain, and sun. But decoration appeared almost immediately.

discovery.text: 70,000-year-old shell beads suggest humans adorned themselves long before agriculture. Fashion predates civilization.

twist.text: Function never disappeared. It just got buried. A business suit 'protects' social standing, not skin.

climax.text: Fashion is the only art form worn on the body. It's simultaneously personal expression and social communication.

punchline.text: We didn't just learn to dress. We learned to speak with fabric.

quiz.question: What do 70,000-year-old shell beads tell us about early humans?
options: Self-adornment and fashion predate civilization
Ancient humans traded shells as currency
Shell beads were used as tools, not decoration

topics.title: Textiles: The Technology Behind Fashion

hook.text: Silk was so valuable that China guarded its production as a state secret for 3,000 years. Smuggling it meant death.

buildup.text: Textiles are the foundation of fashion: cotton, wool, silk, linen, and later synthetics like nylon and polyester.

discovery.text: Each fiber has unique properties. Silk drapes elegantly. Wool insulates wet or dry. Linen breathes in heat.

twist.text: The Industrial Revolution mechanized weaving. What once took weeks by hand could be produced in hours.

climax.text: Synthetic fibers (1930s onwards) made clothing cheaper but created an environmental crisis.

punchline.text: Fashion starts with thread. The thread determines everything that follows.

quiz.question: Why did China guard silk production as a state secret?
options: Silk was extraordinarily valuable â€” its production was protected for 3,000 years
Silkworms were considered sacred animals
Silk was used exclusively for military uniforms

topics.title: The Corset: Beauty, Power, and Controversy

hook.text: The corset shaped Western fashion for 400 years.

buildup.text: Corsets appeared in the 16th century, creating an idealized hourglass silhouette through boning and tight lacing.

discovery.text: They were engineering: whalebone, steel, and precise construction. A well-made corset was both craft and architecture.

twist.text: Were they oppressive or empowering?

climax.text: Paul Poiret abolished the corset in 1906, liberating women's bodies.

punchline.text: The corset is gone. The debate about whose body fashion serves is not.

quiz.question: Who is credited with liberating fashion from the corset?
options: Paul Poiret, who introduced loose, uncorseted silhouettes around 1906
Queen Victoria, who banned corsets in 1850
Coco Chanel, who replaced them with jersey fabric

topics.title: Haute Couture: The Birth of Fashion Design

hook.text: Charles Frederick Worth sewed his name into garments in the 1850s. Before him, dressmakers were anonymous.

buildup.text: Haute couture means 'high sewing' â€” custom-fitted garments made by hand in Paris ateliers.

discovery.text: Worth created seasonal collections, fashion shows, and the idea that a designer â€” not the client â€” dictates the design.

twist.text: Today, fewer than 15 houses officially qualify as haute couture. It's legally protected in France. Rules are strict.

climax.text: Couture loses money. But it builds brand prestige that sells millions in perfume, bags, and ready-to-wear.

punchline.text: Haute couture isn't about selling dresses. It's about selling dreams.

quiz.question: Why is haute couture important for fashion houses despite losing money?
options: It builds prestige that drives sales of perfume, accessories, and ready-to-wear
It satisfies legal requirements in France
It trains new designers for the industry

topics.title: The Roaring Twenties: Flappers and Freedom

hook.text: Hemlines rose above the knee for the first time in Western history.

buildup.text: Post-WWI, women entered the workforce.

discovery.text: Coco Chanel championed comfort: jersey fabric, trousers, and the little black dress.

twist.text: The freedom was partial. The boyish, flat-chested ideal was just a different body standard, not the absence of one.

climax.text: Art Deco geometry influenced fashion: zigzag patterns, metallic fabrics, and angular cuts mirrored architecture and art.

punchline.text: The flapper didn't just shorten the skirt.

quiz.question: What social change drove 1920s flapper fashion?
options: Women entering the workforce and seeking liberation after WWI
A fabric shortage that required shorter garments
Government regulations on clothing length

topics.title: Christian Dior's New Look: Post-War Glamour

hook.text: In 1947, Christian Dior used 20 yards of fabric for one skirt. Post-war fabric was rationed.

buildup.text: The 'New Look' featured nipped waists, padded hips, full skirts, and rounded shoulders .

discovery.text: Women had worn practical, fabric-saving styles during WWII.

twist.text: Feminists protested: the New Look put women back in restrictive silhouettes. Liberation through fashion went backward.

climax.text: Despite controversy, it dominated fashion for a decade and established Paris as the global fashion capital again.

punchline.text: The New Look wasn't just about clothes.

quiz.question: Why was Dior's New Look controversial?
options: It used excessive fabric during rationing and put women back in restrictive silhouettes
The colors were considered inappropriate
It was too similar to pre-war fashion

topics.title: The Swinging Sixties: Youth Takes Over Fashion

hook.text: Mary Quant's miniskirt shocked the world in 1964. Hemlines went to mid-thigh. Parents were horrified. Youth didn't care.

buildup.text: The 1960s shifted fashion power from Parisian couturiers to London's young designers. Youth culture drove the industry.

discovery.text: Pop art, space race aesthetics, and mod culture influenced fashion: bold patterns, geometric prints, PVC.

twist.text: AndrÃ© CourrÃ¨ges also claims credit for the miniskirt. The debate is unresolved â€” but the revolution was undeniable.

climax.text: Twiggy became fashion's first supermodel at 16. The industry learned: youth sells, and it sells fast.

punchline.text: The sixties proved that fashion doesn't trickle down from elites.

quiz.question: How did the 1960s change the power structure of fashion?
options: Youth culture and London street fashion overtook Paris couture
Paris strengthened its dominance over global fashion
Fashion became less accessible to young people

topics.title: Coco Chanel: The Woman Who Invented Modern Fashion

hook.text: Before Chanel, women wore corsets. After Chanel, women wore comfort.

buildup.text: Gabrielle 'Coco' Chanel introduced jersey fabric, the little black dress, costume jewelry, and the Chanel No. 5 perfume.

discovery.text: She borrowed from menswear: trousers, blazers, and loose fits. Comfort wasn't masculine â€” she made it chic.

twist.text: Her wartime collaboration with Nazi Germany tainted her legacy. Fashion history often sanitizes uncomfortable truths.

climax.text: The Chanel suit â€” collarless jacket, gold buttons, A-line skirt â€” remains fashion's most copied design, 70 years on.

punchline.text: Chanel freed women from decoration. She dressed them in confidence.

quiz.question: What was Coco Chanel's most revolutionary contribution to fashion?
options: Introducing comfort and menswear-inspired simplicity for women
Creating the first color-printed fabric
Designing the first high-heeled shoe

topics.title: Yves Saint Laurent: Art Meets Fashion

hook.text: Yves Saint Laurent put women in tuxedos. 'Le Smoking' in 1966 was scandalous.

buildup.text: YSL became head of Dior at 21, then launched his own house. He blurred gender lines and brought art into clothing.

discovery.text: His Mondrian dress (1965) turned Piet Mondrian's paintings into fashion. Art walked off the canvas and onto the body.

twist.text: He pioneered ready-to-wear luxury with Rive Gauche (1966). High fashion became accessible without losing prestige.

climax.text: Safari jackets, sheer blouses, jumpsuits â€” YSL consistently gave women clothes borrowed from male power.

punchline.text: YSL didn't dress women as women. He dressed women as equals.

quiz.question: What was revolutionary about YSL's 'Le Smoking' tuxedo for women?
options: It gave women access to masculine power dressing â€” and was scandalously controversial
It was the first affordable tuxedo
It introduced color to formal menswear

topics.title: Alexander McQueen: Fashion as Dark Art

hook.text: McQueen's 1999 show had a model in a white dress spray-painted by robots in real time. Fashion as live performance art.

buildup.text: Lee Alexander McQueen fused technical tailoring with emotional storytelling.

discovery.text: Trained on Savile Row, he could construct garments as precisely as any couturier. Skill fueled his rebellion.

twist.text: His shows addressed trauma, colonialism, and nature's destruction. Fashion critics debated: is this art or shock value?

climax.text: His skull-print scarf became fashion's most copied accessory.

punchline.text: McQueen didn't make pretty clothes.

quiz.question: What set Alexander McQueen apart from other fashion designers?
options: He combined precise technical tailoring with emotional, theatrical storytelling
He used only synthetic materials
He designed exclusively for men

topics.title: Vivienne Westwood: Punk's Fashion Godmother

hook.text: Vivienne Westwood dressed the Sex Pistols. Safety pins, ripped shirts, and bondage straps became punk's uniform.

buildup.text: From her London shop SEX (later Seditionaries), Westwood turned anti-fashion rebellion into an actual fashion movement.

discovery.text: Punk fashion was political: DIY aesthetics, destruction of luxury codes, and visible anger against the establishment.

twist.text: Westwood later became a respected haute couture designer. The rebel joined the establishment she once attacked.

climax.text: She spent her final decades as a fierce climate activist, using fashion shows to protest environmental destruction.

punchline.text: Westwood proved that fashion can be a weapon. She never stopped fighting.

quiz.question: How did Vivienne Westwood connect punk culture to fashion?
options: She dressed the Sex Pistols and turned DIY rebellion into a fashion movement
She organized the first punk music festival
She wrote the punk manifesto that inspired musicians

topics.title: Punk Fashion: DIY Rebellion on the Body

hook.text: Ripped jeans, safety pins, mohawks, and band patches. Punk fashion was designed to offend. That was the whole point.

buildup.text: 1970s punk rejected mainstream fashion entirely. If fashion said 'polish,' punk said 'destroy.

discovery.text: DIY was the philosophy: customize, rip, patch, and repurpose. Looking 'bad' on purpose was a deliberate skill.

twist.text: High fashion quickly co-opted punk. Versace used safety pins on a $10,000 dress. Rebellion was commodified.

climax.text: Every generation's youth movement borrows from punk: grunge, emo, streetwear.

punchline.text: Punk's greatest fashion statement: you don't need permission to be yourself.

quiz.question: What happened when high fashion adopted punk aesthetics?
options: Rebellion was commodified â€” safety pins appeared on luxury garments
Punk designers became wealthy and abandoned the movement
High fashion audiences rejected punk completely

topics.title: Hip-Hop Fashion: From the Streets to the Runway

hook.text: Baggy jeans, gold chains, Timberland boots, and oversized jerseys.

buildup.text: 1980s-90s hip-hop style reflected street culture: sportswear brands (Adidas, Nike), logo-heavy luxury.

discovery.text: Run-DMC's 'My Adidas' (1986) was fashion's first celebrity-brand deal. Sneakers became cultural currency overnight.

twist.text: Luxury brands initially rejected hip-hop.

climax.text: Virgil Abloh (Off-White, Louis Vuitton) bridged streetwear and haute couture.

punchline.text: Hip-hop didn't ask for fashion's approval. It took fashion over.

quiz.question: What was significant about Run-DMC's deal with Adidas?
options: It was fashion's first major celebrity-brand partnership
They designed the first Adidas shoe
They boycotted Nike to support Adidas

topics.title: Japanese Fashion: Deconstructing Western Rules

hook.text: Rei Kawakubo sent models down the Paris runway in ripped, asymmetric, black garments. Critics called it 'Hiroshima chic.

buildup.text: 1980s Japanese designers â€” Kawakubo, Yamamoto, Miyake â€” challenged Western fashion's obsession with the body, color.

discovery.text: They used draping, wrapping, and oversized shapes that concealed rather than revealed the body.

twist.text: Western fashion was about showing the body.

climax.text: Issey Miyake's pleating technology turned flat fabric into 3D garments. Function, beauty, and innovation merged.

punchline.text: Japanese fashion didn't break Western rules.

quiz.question: How did 1980s Japanese designers challenge Western fashion?
options: They used asymmetry, oversized shapes, and anti-fit designs that didn't reveal the body
They introduced brighter colors and tighter fits
They copied Parisian couture and made it cheaper

topics.title: Streetwear: How Skate Culture Became Luxury

hook.text: A Supreme brick sold for $30. A box-logo t-shirt resells for $1,000. Streetwear turned scarcity into religion.

buildup.text: Streetwear emerged from 1990s skate, surf, and hip-hop culture: graphic tees, hoodies, sneakers, and limited drops.

discovery.text: James Jebbia (Supreme), Shawn Stussy, and Nigo (A Bathing Ape) built brands on authenticity, community.

twist.text: Luxury brands initially mocked streetwear. Then Louis Vuitton Ã— Supreme happened (2017). The hierarchy collapsed.

climax.text: Streetwear rewrote fashion's business model: drop culture, resale markets.

punchline.text: Streetwear didn't climb the fashion ladder. It built its own.

quiz.question: How did streetwear change fashion's traditional business model?
options: It replaced seasonal collections with limited drops, resale markets, and hype culture
It made all fashion free and accessible
It eliminated the need for physical stores

topics.title: Fast Fashion: Speed, Scale, and Consequences

hook.text: Zara can go from design to store shelf in 15 days. Traditional fashion takes 6 months. Speed changed everything.

buildup.text: Fast fashion replicates runway trends quickly and cheaply: H&M, Zara, Shein.

discovery.text: It democratized fashion. Trendy clothes became affordable. But the human and environmental costs are staggering.

twist.text: The fashion industry produces 10% of global carbon emissions â€” more than aviation and shipping combined.

climax.text: The Rana Plaza factory collapse (2013) killed 1,134 workers. It exposed the true cost of $5 t-shirts.

punchline.text: Fast fashion made clothes disposable. The planet is paying the price.

quiz.question: How quickly can Zara take a design from concept to store shelf?
options: About 15 days â€” compared to 6 months for traditional fashion
About 6 months â€” same as traditional fashion
About 2 years â€” slower due to quality control

topics.title: Sustainable Fashion: The Industry's Reckoning

hook.text: 92 million tons of textile waste are produced every year.

buildup.text: Sustainable fashion aims to reduce environmental impact through ethical sourcing, slow production, and circular design.

discovery.text: Circular fashion designs clothes to be repaired, resold, or recycled.

twist.text: Many brands 'greenwash' â€” claiming sustainability while barely changing practices.

climax.text: Stella McCartney, Eileen Fisher, and Reformation prove luxury and sustainability can coexist .

punchline.text: Sustainable fashion isn't a trend. It's a survival requirement for the industry.

quiz.question: What is 'greenwashing' in the fashion industry?
options: Brands falsely claiming sustainability while barely changing practices
Dyeing all fabrics green for eco-branding
A washing technique that reduces water usage

topics.title: Fashion Weeks: The Industry's Grand Stage

hook.text: New York, London, Milan, Paris â€” in that order, twice a year. Fashion Weeks set the trends the entire world follows.

buildup.text: Fashion Weeks originated in 1940s New York as 'Press Week' â€” a way to showcase American design during wartime.

discovery.text: Designers present collections 6 months ahead of the selling season. What you see in February ships in September.

twist.text: Social media disrupted the model. Shows are now live-streamed.

climax.text: Some designers now show 'see now, buy now' collections â€” available immediately. The 6-month lag is under attack.

punchline.text: Fashion Weeks still set the agenda. But who controls the front row is changing.

quiz.question: How far in advance are Fashion Week collections shown before they're available to buy?
options: About 6 months â€” what shows in February ships in September
1 month â€” collections are available almost immediately
2 years â€” to allow for production planning

topics.title: The Power of the Fashion Editor

hook.text: Anna Wintour sits front row at every show. Designers court her approval. A Vogue feature can make or break a career.

buildup.text: Fashion editors â€” at Vogue, Harper's Bazaar, Elle â€” curate trends, champion designers, and shape public taste.

discovery.text: Diana Vreeland (Vogue, 1960s) declared 'pink is the navy blue of India.' She didn't report trends â€” she invented them.

twist.text: Social media influencers now rival editors' power. A TikTok viral moment reaches more people than any magazine cover.

climax.text: The industry is shifting from top-down tastemaking to democratized influence. But elite gatekeepers still set the tone.

punchline.text: Fashion editors don't follow trends. They decide which ones exist.

quiz.question: How have social media influencers changed fashion's power structure?
options: They rival traditional editors by reaching larger audiences and democratizing trend-setting
They have no impact on fashion industry decisions
They only promote fast fashion brands

topics.title: Fashion and Gender: Breaking Binary Dress Codes

hook.text: Harry Styles wore a dress on the cover of Vogue.

buildup.text: For centuries, Western fashion enforced binary dress codes: trousers for men, skirts for women. Deviation meant scandal.

discovery.text: Gender-fluid fashion rejects the binary: unisex collections, men in skirts, women in suiting. Designers challenge norms.

twist.text: Historically, gender-neutral clothing was normal. In many cultures, robes, tunics, and wraps served all genders.

climax.text: Brands like Telfar, Harris Reed, and Palomo Spain build identities around genderless design.

punchline.text: Clothes don't have a gender. People decided they should. People can undecide.

quiz.question: Is gender-specific clothing historically universal?
options: No â€” many cultures historically used gender-neutral garments like robes and tunics
Yes â€” all cultures have always had strict gendered dress codes
Gender in clothing only became relevant in the 21st century

topics.title: Fashion as Political Protest

hook.text: Suffragettes wore white to symbolize purity. Black Panthers wore leather and berets. Clothing is always political.

buildup.text: Throughout history, clothing has communicated resistance: Gandhi's khadi, Mandela's Madiba shirt.

discovery.text: What you wear can signal solidarity, defiance, or identity. Fashion is a visible, daily form of political speech.

twist.text: Brands co-opt political fashion for profit.

climax.text: Melania Trump's 'I Don't Really Care, Do U?' jacket proved fashion statements cut both ways.

punchline.text: You can't opt out of fashion politics. Even 'no statement' is a statement.

quiz.question: Why did Gandhi wear hand-spun khadi cloth?
options: As political resistance against British textile imports and colonialism
Because it was the most fashionable fabric in India
Khadi was the only fabric available during the drought

topics.title: The Little Black Dress: Fashion's Most Democratic Garment

hook.text: Audrey Hepburn in Breakfast at Tiffany's. A simple black dress. No jewels needed.

buildup.text: Coco Chanel introduced the Little Black Dress (LBD) in 1926.

discovery.text: Before Chanel, black was for mourning. She made it chic. Black became elegance, simplicity, and quiet confidence.

twist.text: The LBD's power is its blankness. Accessories, styling, and attitude transform it. One garment, infinite identities.

climax.text: From cocktail parties to red carpets to job interviews, the LBD remains fashion's safest and most versatile choice.

punchline.text: The LBD proved: the simplest design is often the most powerful.

quiz.question: Why was the little black dress revolutionary when Chanel introduced it?
options: Black was previously reserved for mourning â€” Chanel made it chic and universal
Black fabric was the most expensive at the time
No designer had ever used the color black before

topics.title: Cultural Appropriation vs. Appreciation in Fashion

hook.text: Gucci sold a $790 'turban.' Sikh communities pointed out they wear turbans as religious practice.

buildup.text: Cultural appropriation occurs when dominant cultures borrow elements from marginalized ones without credit, context.

discovery.text: The line between appreciation and appropriation: credit, collaboration, and whether the originating culture benefits.

twist.text: Fashion has always mixed cultures. The question isn't whether to borrow â€” it's how, and who profits.

climax.text: Brands like Dior now collaborate with indigenous artisans, sharing profits and credit. The model is evolving.

punchline.text: Appreciation asks. Appropriation takes. The difference is respect.

quiz.question: What distinguishes cultural appreciation from cultural appropriation in fashion?
options: Credit, collaboration, and whether the originating culture benefits
Only the price of the garment matters
Any cultural mixing is automatically appropriation

topics.title: The Sneaker: From Sport to Status Symbol

hook.text: Michael Jordan's first Air Jordans (1985) were banned by the NBA. Nike paid the fine every game.

buildup.text: Sneakers began as rubber-soled athletic shoes in the 1800s.

discovery.text: Sneaker culture turned athletic footwear into collectible art. Limited editions resell for thousands.

twist.text: The sneaker resale market is worth $10 billion+. A pair of shoes can appreciate faster than stocks.

climax.text: Collaborations (Nike Ã— Off-White, Adidas Ã— Yeezy) merge fashion, music, and sport into cultural events.

punchline.text: Sneakers aren't footwear anymore. They're cultural currency.

quiz.question: Why did the NBA ban Michael Jordan's first Air Jordans?
options: They violated the league's uniform color policy â€” Nike paid the fine for every game
They gave Jordan an unfair athletic advantage
Other players complained about the bright colors

topics.title: The Fashion Cycle: Trends That Return

hook.text: Mom jeans were 'uncool' in 2005, 'ironic' in 2015, and 'essential' by 2020. Fashion is a circle, not a line.

buildup.text: The fashion cycle follows a pattern: introduction, rise, peak, decline, and eventually â€” revival.

discovery.text: Nostalgia drives revivals. Gen Z revives Y2K fashion. Millennials revived 90s grunge.

twist.text: Social media accelerated the cycle. Micro-trends now rise and fall in weeks, not years. The cycle is spinning faster.

climax.text: Some items transcend cycles: white t-shirts, blue jeans, black blazers. 'Classics' are trends that refused to die.

punchline.text: If you keep your old clothes long enough, they become fashionable again.

quiz.question: How long is the typical fashion revival cycle?
options: About 20-30 years â€” each generation rediscovers past trends
About 5 years â€” trends repeat rapidly
About 100 years â€” only major historical revivals occur

topics.title: Digital Fashion: Clothes That Don't Exist

hook.text: A digital-only dress sold for $9,500 in 2019. It was photoshopped onto the buyer.

buildup.text: Digital fashion creates garments that exist only in virtual spaces: social media filters, gaming avatars.

discovery.text: It produces zero waste, requires no shipping, and allows unlimited creative freedom â€” physics doesn't apply.

twist.text: If fashion is about identity and status, does the garment need to physically exist? Digital fashion says no.

climax.text: Balenciaga designed for Fortnite. Gucci sold virtual bags on Roblox. Fashion is entering the virtual economy.

punchline.text: The next fashion revolution might not involve fabric at all.

quiz.question: What advantage does digital fashion have over physical fashion?
options: Zero waste, no shipping, and unlimited creative freedom beyond physical constraints
It's always cheaper than physical clothing
Digital clothes last forever without degrading

topics.title: Giorgio Armani: The Man Who Softened Power Dressing

hook.text: Armani removed the stiff lining from men's blazers. A jacket that moved like fabric, not armor.

buildup.text: In the 1980s, power suits were rigid, padded, and aggressive.

discovery.text: He dressed Richard Gere in American Gigolo (1980).

twist.text: He applied the same philosophy to womenswear: borrowing from menswear to create androgynous elegance.

climax.text: Armani built a $10 billion empire across fashion, home, hotels, and restaurants â€” the most diversified designer brand.

punchline.text: Armani proved that power doesn't need to look hard. It can look easy.

quiz.question: What was revolutionary about Armani's approach to the men's blazer?
options: He removed the stiff lining, creating a relaxed yet authoritative silhouette
He added extra padding for a broader shoulder look
He was the first to make blazers in colors other than black

topics.title: Fashion Weeks: How Runway Shows Shape Trends

hook.text: Four cities, four weeks, thousands of looks. Fashion Week isn't just a show â€” it decides what the world wears next.

buildup.text: The 'Big Four' â€” New York, London, Milan, Paris â€” host seasonal fashion weeks that set global trends months in advance.

discovery.text: Runway shows serve three purposes: showcase designs, attract press coverage, and signal to retailers what to buy.

twist.text: Front-row seats aren't purchased. They're earned by influence. A celebrity sighting can make a collection go viral.

climax.text: Alexander McQueen's 1999 show featured a model on a rotating platform being spray-painted by robots. Art met fashion.

punchline.text: Fashion Week doesn't follow trends. It creates them.

quiz.question: What is the primary purpose of Fashion Week runway shows?
options: To showcase designs, attract press, and signal buying trends to retailers
To sell clothes directly to the public at discounted prices
To award prizes to the best new designers each season

topics.title: The Little Black Dress: Fashion's Most Enduring Icon

hook.text: In 1926, Vogue published a sketch of a simple black dress by Chanel and predicted it would become 'a sort of uniform.'

buildup.text: Before Chanel, black was reserved for mourning. She turned it into elegance, simplicity, and effortless style.

discovery.text: The little black dress works because it's a blank canvas: dress it up with jewelry, dress it down with flats.

twist.text: Gianni Versace once said the LBD is 'the hardest thing to design' â€” its simplicity leaves no room to hide flaws.

climax.text: Audrey Hepburn's black Givenchy dress in Breakfast at Tiffany's became the most famous LBD in cinema history.

punchline.text: The little black dress proved that simplicity is fashion's greatest luxury.

quiz.question: Who popularized the little black dress as everyday elegance?
options: Coco Chanel, who transformed black from mourning to chic in the 1920s
Christian Dior with his New Look collection
Audrey Hepburn in Breakfast at Tiffany's

topics.title: Fast Fashion vs. Slow Fashion: An Ethical Divide

hook.text: A $5 t-shirt has a hidden cost. Someone, somewhere, paid the price that you didn't.

buildup.text: Fast fashion brands produce 52 'micro-seasons' per year, turning trends from runway to rack in days, not months.

discovery.text: Slow fashion counters with fewer pieces, ethical sourcing, durable materials, and transparent supply chains.

twist.text: Fast fashion brands now market 'sustainable' lines. Critics say it's greenwashing â€” you can't be sustainable at scale.

climax.text: The 2013 Rana Plaza collapse killed 1,134 workers. It became the catalyst for the Fashion Revolution movement.

punchline.text: Cheap clothes aren't cheap. Someone else is paying the real price.

quiz.question: What event catalyzed the global Fashion Revolution movement?
options: The 2013 Rana Plaza factory collapse in Bangladesh that killed over 1,000 workers
A major fashion show boycott in Paris
The launch of the first sustainable fashion brand
